snippet.title: Donald Trump convicted of falsifying business records in hush money scheme
snippet.description: In a historic verdict, former President Donald Trump was convicted of falsifying business records in connection to a hush money payment to Stormy Daniels. #CNN #News

@@moxy666 The jury was handpicked by the Judge, my dude.  The Judge also gave jury instruction in a way that influenced them to convict. The Judge also restricted counter testimony that the jury may have found to raise a reasonable doubt.  So yes, the Judge very heavily influences the verdict.  Do you even know about any of these details?

​@@mastrtonberry2 The judge has no say whatsoever in jury selection. It's drawn from a random lottery of voter rolls and driver's license registry, and each side's legal counsel can each vet out and replace several of them with no requirement to provide justification. The only thing the judge does in that process is enforce order if someone starts being a jackass.

His instructions to the jury were a) that intentionally instructing someone else to commit a crime additionally makes you liable for that crime yourself (direct citation of law), b) that each charge represented one specific falsified document (objective fact, and clarification to the scope of each charge and that they must be considered separately), and c) to be a felony as charged, the defendant must be proven beyond reasonable doubt to have committed that crime in order to commit or conceal another crime (direct of citation of law). If anything, b and c make it more difficult to convict Trump of all charges by compartmentalizing them and raising the standard of confidence necessary for each one.

The defense testimony by Brad Smith was restricted in scope, which is something judges do when they know the legal counsel in question plans to use them to either interpret law themselves (literally not a witness's job) or chatter far outside of the material specifics of the case (wasting everyone's time). This happens quite frequently, because defense teams with no actual defense tend to do that a lot and it causes a massive and pointless burden on the judicial system when they're allowed to do it -- and we know that was their plan, because Trump's own team backed out of calling Smith when Merchan predicted their intent.

video_comments.comment_text:
Donald Trump was found guilty Thursday of falsifying business records to cover up a hush money payment to a porn star, making him the first former president to become a convicted felon.

The unanimous verdict from the 12-person jury ends a six-week trial in which prosecutors accused Trump of orchestrating an illegal conspiracy to influence the 2016 presidential election.

As the jury foreperson read the verdict, Trump looked toward the jury box. After the foreperson finished reading the verdict, the former president looked straight ahead, appearing somewhat red in the face. Then, as the jurors individually confirmed that they agreed with the verdict, Trump stared at them.

It now falls to the judge, Justice Juan Merchan, to determine Trump’s sentence. He scheduled the sentencing for July 11, four days before the Republican National Convention begins.

Falsifying business records carries a maximum sentence of four years in prison, but because the crime is nonviolent and Trump has no prior convictions, any prison time is far from guaranteed. Merchan could opt instead for home confinement, probation or a milder form of supervised release.

Trump is certain to appeal the verdict — a process that could take many months or even years. Meanwhile, he stands accused of additional wide-ranging criminal conduct in three other cases: two for subverting the 2020 election results and one for hoarding classified documents after he left office. But none of those cases appears likely to go to trial before Election Day.

Despite its historic nature, there is scant evidence that Trump’s conviction in the hush money case will drastically alter his prospects in the 2024 race. He has a small lead over President Joe Biden in many swing-state polls — a lead that held steady throughout the trial.

One reason for the likely lack of fallout is that the payoff at the center of the case, and the events surrounding it, have long been publicly known: The Wall Street Journal first revealed them in 2018. And since the trial was not televised, the details of the legal proceedings have remained opaque to many voters.

Recent polls have shown that most Americans saw the hush money case as less serious than Trump’s other three. A Quinnipiac University poll conducted in mid-May found that 46 percent of respondents believed Trump had done something illegal in the hush-money payment case, 29 percent said he had done something unethical but not illegal, and 21 percent said he did nothing wrong.

And Trump’s allies in the GOP stuck by him throughout the trial: A rotating cast of elected Republicans and other surrogates joined him at the lower Manhattan courthouse most days.

The jury of seven men and five women deliberated for a day and a half before issuing its guilty verdict.

The panel found that Trump falsified business documents that reflected a series of payments he made to his former lawyer, Michael Cohen. Those payments reimbursed Cohen for $130,000 in hush money that he sent to porn star Stormy Daniels 12 days before the 2016 election. At the time, Daniels was threatening to go public with her account of having had sex with Trump a decade earlier.


Trump, with Cohen as a middle man, struck a non-disclosure deal with Daniels to ensure her claims didn’t damage his White House bid. But when Trump later reimbursed Cohen, he falsely designated the money as legal expenses in his company’s books.

Prosecutors from the Manhattan district attorney’s office charged Trump with 34 felony counts, accusing him of falsifying 11 invoice records, 12 general ledger entries and 11 checks, some of which were signed by Trump with a black Sharpie.

In order to find Trump guilty, the jury had to conclude beyond a reasonable doubt not only that Trump falsified the records with a fraudulent intent, but also that Trump did so to commit or conceal another crime. That underlying crime, prosecutors argued, was a violation of a New York state election law that prohibits conspiring to promote a candidate by “unlawful means.” The hush money to Daniels, prosecutors said, was unlawful because it violated campaign finance laws. And they said Trump’s reimbursement arrangement to Cohen violated tax laws as well.

@tomfoolery1966  Since it was a jury trial, the only grounds for appeal will be for procedural reasons. To file an appeal for procedure, the defense has to object during the trial to anything they see as a procedural error for it to be appealed later. When you look over the trial record, you see the defense didn't really provide themselves with many(or any) opportunities for a credible procedural complaint. The likelihood of there being any sort of successful appeal resulting in the verdict or sentence being overturned is very, very small.

I'm sure they'll try very hard nevertheless, it will be interesting to see if those appeals achieve anything
